NAPLAN for Students with Additional Needs

Comprehensive guidance on accommodations, support, and participation options for students with disabilities or diverse learning needs during NAPLAN testing.

Understanding Inclusive Assessment

NAPLAN is designed to be inclusive, ensuring all students can participate regardless of disability or learning needs. The program provides reasonable adjustments to remove barriers while maintaining the integrity of the assessment. This means students with additional needs can demonstrate their true abilities without being disadvantaged by their condition.

Queensland education authorities work with schools to implement the Disability Discrimination Act and Disability Standards for Education, ensuring equitable access to NAPLAN. The focus is on assessing what students know and can do, not on their disability or learning difference.

Many parents worry that accommodations might give an unfair advantage, but research shows that appropriate adjustments simply level the playing field. Students receive the support they need to show their actual capabilities, not artificial boosts.

Eligibility for Accommodations

Who Qualifies

Accommodations are available for students with:

  • Physical disabilities: Mobility impairments, chronic health conditions
  • Sensory impairments: Vision or hearing difficulties
  • Learning disabilities: Dyslexia, ADHD, processing disorders
  • Intellectual disabilities: Cognitive impairments affecting learning
  • Medical conditions: Temporary or chronic health issues
  • Mental health conditions: Anxiety, depression affecting test performance
  • Language barriers: English as additional language with significant impact

Documentation Requirements

To access accommodations, schools typically require:

  • Professional assessment: Psychologist, speech pathologist, or medical reports
  • School documentation: Evidence of impact on learning or test performance
  • Individual Education Plans: Current IEP or similar support documentation
  • Medical certificates: For temporary conditions or health-related needs

Application Process

  • Early notification: Schools should be informed by Term 1
  • Application forms: Queensland Department of Education accommodation requests
  • Principal approval: School-level decisions for most accommodations
  • State-level review: Complex cases may require departmental approval
  • Appeals process: Available if applications are denied

Types of Accommodations Available

Timing and Scheduling Adjustments

Flexible timing to accommodate different needs:

  • Extended time: Additional time (typically 25% or 50% extra)
  • Rest breaks: Scheduled breaks during testing sessions
  • Separate timing: Testing outside standard school hours
  • Multiple sessions: Breaking tests into shorter segments over days
  • Alternative scheduling: Different days or times to accommodate needs

Physical and Environmental Support

  • Separate room: Quiet, distraction-free testing environment
  • Special furniture: Adapted seating, desks, or equipment
  • Lighting adjustments: Appropriate lighting for visual needs
  • Acoustic considerations: Soundproofing or noise reduction
  • Temperature control: Comfortable testing conditions

Assistive Technology and Tools

  • Screen readers: Text-to-speech software for reading components
  • Magnification: Enlarged text or zoom functions
  • Voice recognition: Speech-to-text for writing components
  • Alternative keyboards: Adapted input devices
  • Braille materials: Tactile test formats
  • Calculator access: For numeracy components (with approval)

Human Support

  • Reader assistance: Trained personnel reading test questions
  • Scribe support: Writing responses for students unable to write
  • Sign language interpreters: For deaf or hard-of-hearing students
  • Personal care assistance: Support for medical or personal needs
  • Proximity supervision: Closer monitoring for behavioral needs

Format Modifications

  • Simplified language: Plain English versions of questions
  • Visual supports: Diagrams, pictures, or graphic organizers
  • Color overlays: For visual processing difficulties
  • Reduced content: Shorter test versions for some disabilities
  • Alternative response formats: Verbal responses or pointing instead of writing

Special Provisions for Specific Needs

Students with Physical Disabilities

Accommodations focus on access and independence:

  • Mobility support: Wheelchair access, adapted furniture
  • Writing assistance: Scribes or voice recognition for those unable to write
  • Extended time: Additional time for physical fatigue
  • Medical breaks: Scheduled breaks for medication or treatment
  • Assistive devices: Specialized equipment approved for use

Students with Learning Disabilities

  • Extra time: 25-100% additional time depending on documentation
  • Separate environment: Reduced distractions and noise
  • Reader/scribe: Support for decoding or writing difficulties
  • Text magnification: Larger fonts for visual processing issues
  • Break provisions: Regular breaks to manage fatigue

Students with Sensory Impairments

  • Braille materials: Tactile test formats for blind students
  • Audio versions: Screen readers or recorded tests
  • Sign language: Interpreters for deaf students
  • Visual enhancements: Magnification or large print
  • Acoustic adjustments: Hearing loops or sound amplification

Students with Medical Conditions

  • Medical breaks: Time for medication, treatment, or rest
  • Flexible scheduling: Testing at optimal times of day
  • Separate accommodation: Private room for medical needs
  • Shortened sessions: Breaking tests into manageable segments
  • Medical equipment: Access to necessary devices

Students with Mental Health Needs

  • Reduced anxiety: Familiar test administrators or environments
  • Break provisions: Regular breaks to manage stress
  • Separate testing: Quiet, low-stimulation environment
  • Emotional support: Access to counselors if needed
  • Flexible timing: Testing when anxiety is typically lower

Parental Role and Advocacy

Working with Schools

Parents play a crucial role in ensuring appropriate accommodations:

  • Open communication: Discuss needs early and maintain ongoing dialogue
  • Provide documentation: Share reports, assessments, and medical information
  • Attend meetings: Participate in accommodation planning discussions
  • Share insights: Explain how your child's needs affect test performance
  • Follow up: Ensure accommodations are implemented correctly

Understanding Your Rights

  • Disability Discrimination Act: Legal protection against unfair treatment
  • Reasonable adjustments: Schools must provide appropriate accommodations
  • Appeal processes: Options if accommodations are denied
  • Independent advocacy: Support from disability advocacy organizations
  • Departmental support: Queensland Education resources for families

Preparing Your Child

  • Explain accommodations: Help them understand the support they'll receive
  • Practice with supports: Familiarize them with assistive technology or procedures
  • Build confidence: Emphasize that accommodations help show true abilities
  • Address concerns: Discuss any worries about being "different"
  • Positive framing: Focus on participation and effort, not comparison with others

Alternative Assessment Options

When Standard Testing Isn't Appropriate

For some students with significant disabilities, standard NAPLAN may not be suitable. Alternative options include:

  • Exemption: Complete withdrawal from NAPLAN with principal approval
  • Alternative assessment: Modified testing focusing on individual curriculum
  • Portfolio assessment: Collection of work samples over time
  • School-based assessment: Teacher-developed assessment tools

Exemption Criteria

Exemptions are considered when:

  • Severe disability: Significant impact on all areas of functioning
  • Medical conditions: Severe illness preventing participation
  • Developmental delays: Functioning well below age expectations
  • Educational inappropriateness: Test content not aligned with abilities

Reporting for Exempt Students

  • Alternative measures: School reports on progress and achievements
  • Individual plans: Focus on personal learning goals
  • Qualitative feedback: Descriptive assessment of skills and growth
  • Future participation: Regular review of exemption status

Results and Reporting

Accommodation Notation

NAPLAN reports indicate when accommodations were used:

  • Transparency: Clear notation of adjustments provided
  • Fair comparison: Results compared with similar students, not general population
  • Validity notes: Explanation of how accommodations affect interpretation
  • Confidence levels: Indication of result reliability

Interpreting Results with Accommodations

  • Individual progress: Focus on growth over time rather than absolute scores
  • Context consideration: Understand how accommodations influenced performance
  • Multiple measures: Combine NAPLAN with other assessment data
  • Goal alignment: Compare with individual education plan targets

Using Results Effectively

  • Strength identification: Build on areas of relative strength
  • Support planning: Inform future accommodation and teaching strategies
  • Advocacy tool: Evidence for additional services or funding
  • Progress monitoring: Track development over multiple test administrations

Support Resources

Queensland Education Support

  • Special Education Program: Regional support for students with disabilities
  • Inclusive Education: Resources for diverse learners
  • Accommodation guidelines: Departmental policies and procedures
  • Professional development: Training for teachers and support staff

External Organizations

  • Disability Advocacy Queensland: Support and information for families
  • Learning Difficulties Australia: Resources for specific learning disabilities
  • Australian Association of Special Education: Professional guidance
  • Parent support groups: Local networks and online communities

Professional Services

  • Educational psychologists: Assessment and accommodation recommendations
  • Speech pathologists: Communication and literacy support
  • Occupational therapists: Physical and sensory accommodation advice
  • Counselors: Emotional support and anxiety management

Planning for Future Tests

NAPLAN occurs every three years for most students. Families should:

  • Review accommodations: Assess effectiveness and make adjustments
  • Update documentation: Ensure reports remain current
  • Build familiarity: Practice with similar formats and supports
  • Advocate consistently: Maintain communication with schools
  • Track progress: Monitor development and accommodation needs

The goal of accommodations is to ensure every student can participate meaningfully in NAPLAN, demonstrating their true capabilities. With appropriate support, students with additional needs can show what they know and can do, contributing to a more complete picture of their educational progress.
